p.seg: OF THE SECRETARY OF THE STATE BANKING BOARD SHOWING THE CONDITION OF THE Building and Loan Associations OF NEBRASKA FOR THE YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1914 SUBMITTED TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE STATE BANKING BOARD OCTOBER 1, 1914 By E. ROYSE, Secretary 1914

DEPARTMENT OF RANKING OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA BOARD. Governor, President Auditor of Public Accounts Hon. William B. Howard Hon. Grant G. Martin Attorney General E. Royse Secretaiy Mary Muldoon Heffley Maude Hoge Clerk Assistant Clerk Henry C. Berge Anna Gass Assistant Clerk Stenographer EXAMINERS. E. H. MULLOWNEY Paul Jones M. C. Wilde S. A. Lapp E. N. Van Horne A. D. Touzalin T. R. Riley John Boatsman

Lincoln, October 1, 1914 To his Excellency, John H. Morehead, Governor, Hon. William B. Howard and Hon. Grant G. Martin, The State Banking Board : Ientlemen : — I have the honor to submit herewith the twen - jcond annual report of the Department of Banking, for the od beginning July 1, 1913, and ending June 30, 1914, ving the condition of the building and loan associations of State of Nebraska at the close of business June 30, 1914, piled from annual reports of the several buiiding and associations submitted to the State Banking Board, in irdance with the provisions of the building and loan act, roved April 4, 1899. Tabulated statements, detailed re - s, comparisons and such information and comments touch - this report as are deemed beneficial will be found on the wing pages. I am pleased to inform you that the building and loan asso - ciations under your supervision continue to command the con - fidence of the people, as evidenced by the remarkable growth of the aggregate assets of these institutions, the increase dur - ing the past year being $4,391,686.97. I 'he Nebraska building and loan law has demonstrated the dom of its founders by the progress made by the associa - is operating under its provisions. It is becoming apparent, fever, that in some particulars the law will soon need ending". Such amendments as may be proposed should not made until after careful scrutiny and consideration, as a d law may be easily mutilated by amendments until it be - les a bad law. iwill refer you in particular to one provision of the law t, in my opinion, should receive attention. As the law now nds the amount of stock held by any one person is limited $5,000.00 par value. Inasmuch as the law provides that )an shall not exceed the par value of the stock held by the •rower the maximum loan that can be made is $5,000.00. is was a wise provision at the time the law was enacted, ; conditions have changed and what appeared to be an am - loan provision at the time the law was passed is now

6 TWENTY-SECOND ANNUAL REPORT OF THE found to be entirely inadequate and absurdly constrictive as applied to some of the larger institutions. I will not attempt to recommend a basis for enlarged privileges in the matter of loans, except to state that care should be taken in extending the limit to which a stockholder may invest, and to call atten - tion to the fact that in enlarging the loan limit it will be dan - gerous to consider full paid or matured stock as any part of the basis upon which the limit of loans might be predicated. Ehere are many minor amendments that might be made to law that would enable it to work more smoothly, but the ndment referred to above stands out clearly as an impor - one. E; is often suggested to this department by officers of build - and loan associations, that provision should be made in law for the investment of idle funds of the associations in e, county and municipal securities. Such suggestions are thy of consideration, provided the mutuality of building loan associations is fully protected ; and here again, as a s of investment, full paid and matured stock should be uded for apparent reasons. Pare should be taken in any and all amendments that are red to the law that mutuality, the basis of these associa - s, be fully protected, and that no errors be permitted to p in that would make these institutions a place of refuge the idle funds of the idle rich. Very respectfully, E. ROYSE Secretary State Banking Board.
